name: Hartweg's Golden Sunburst
overview: Hartweg’s Golden Sunburst is an annual herb. It has a thin coating of woolly hairs. Its leaves are yellow in color and linear or lance-shaped and usually grow up to 2.5 centimeters long and often have three small lobes near the tips of the leaves.
habitat: Hartweg’s Golden Sunburst is only found in the Central Valley of California. Grows in grasslands and oak woodland habitats. It prefers to grow in clay heavy soils, mostly along the tops of Mima mounds. Historically, the range of the species extended from Yuba County all the way to south Fresno County, which is a range of 200 miles. The plant became a federally listed in the endangered species of the United States in 1997 due to most of it native ranges being changed by agriculture.
tags: Pseudobahia bahiifolia Hartweg's Golden Sunburst plant yellow flower hairy furry fuzzy plants plant
